Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: MESH: A Hypergraph Analysis Engine for Understanding Large-Scale Social Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid growth in the amount and richness of online interactions through social networking applications is creating data at unprecedented scales. This includes data about individual's characteristics as well as their connections and interactions. Many real-world applications have complex group dynamics involving multiple people. The analysis of such group interactions has the potential to revolutionize social sciences, business, and commerce domains. The goal of this project is to develop a novel computational framework to support scalable analysis of group dynamics in large social networks. The key idea is to explicitly model groups of individuals rather than simply capturing links between pairs of individuals. The broader impacts of this project will consist of enabling richer analysis of complex interactions in real-world networks. It will also enhance the University of Minnesota Computer Science curriculum through courses and research experiences with synergy between the areas of computer systems and data mining.

To model group interactions in networks, this project will use hypergraphs, a generalization of graphs, where hyperedges represent relations between one or more entities. Hypergraphs have the potential to provide higher modeling accuracy for many group phenomena, as well as higher storage and computational efficiency, compared to their graph counterparts. This project will develop an analysis framework called MESH: Minnesota Engine for Scalable evolving Hypergraph analysis, that will provide algorithms and system components to support scalable analysis of evolving hypergraphs. The MESH algorithms will be designed to model and compute several common data-driven questions related to group dynamics in real-world networks. The MESH system-level techniques will be designed to support the execution of these algorithms in a distributed and scalable manner.

For further information see the project web site at: http://mesh.cs.umn.edu

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid growth in the amount and richness of online interactions through social networking applications is creating data at unprecedented scales. This includes data about individuals' characteristics as well as their connections and interactions. Many real-world applications have complex group dynamics involving multiple people. The analysis of such group interactions has the potential to revolutionize social sciences, business, and commerce domains. The goal of this project is to develop a novel computational framework called MESH to support scalable analysis of group dynamics in large social networks. The key idea is to explicitly model groups of individuals rather than simply capturing links between pairs of individuals. The major goals as part of the development of the MESH framework are: (i) to design algorithms to model and compute several common data-driven questions related to group dynamics in real-world networks, and (ii) to develop system-level techniques to enable the computation of these algorithms in a distributed and scalable manner.

This project has developed the MESH software framework on Apache GraphX/Spark (a popular open-source software system), and released the open-source software to the community. MESH has been thoroughly evaluated with multiple datasets and algorithms, on both a local cluster as well as Amazon AWS, and also compared to HyperX, a state-of-the-art system. This project has also explored the synergy between hypergraph algorithms and deep learning, resulting in some new systems, algorithmic, and modeling insights. This project has used temporal hypergraphs to model group evolution and group dynamics in social networks, and modeled the spread of fake news in social networks. This work has resulted in open-source software and multiple publications.

This project has directly supported seven graduate students (including two female) and three undergraduate students. It has resulted in the training and professional development of graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of distributed systems, algorithms, and data mining. This training has resulted in learning systems-level techniques and scheduling algorithms, as well as data mining and statistical techniques and design of algorithms. This training has included learning programming languages, working with open-source software, data analysis of real-world datasets, and use of data mining algorithms. In addition, the development and publication of the work also provided training to students in terms of their writing and presentation skills.
